subject: Re: [junit] Paramaters Collection type
msgSnippet: Done: ID: 2186792 ( https://sourceforge.net/tracker2/?func=detail&aid=2186792&group_id=15278&atid=115278) ... -- Raphael Parree CTO SOA Evangelist Trivera
messageBody:
Done: ID: 2186792 (
https://sourceforge.net/tracker2/?func=detail&aid=2186792&group_id=15278&atid=115278)


On Wed, Oct 22, 2008 at 2:41 PM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:

> Raphael,
>
> You're totally right. Can you open a bug? Thanks,
>
> David Saff
>
>
> On Wed, Oct 22, 2008 at 7:46 AM, rparree <rparree@...<rparree%40gmail.com>>
> wrote:
> >
> > Some additional information how i got to this question:
> >
> > I am referring to the JavaDoc and examples concerning the
> > org.junit.runners.Parameterized. Within this class the computeParams cast
> > the result of the @Parameters method to a List<Object[]>. Therefor i
> believe
> > the JavaDoc should be clearer.
> > The computeParams has been defined private, and is therefor no candidate
> to
> > be overriden by a developer to support another Collection implementation.
> In
> > order to support any other Collection implementation you would have to
> > override the standard createTest. Plus specify that as the your new class
> as
> > the runner.
> >
> > It's just that the JavaDoc for this implementation of Parameterized is
> not
> > accurate, that's was my problem.
> >
> > rparree wrote:
> >>
> >> Hi,
> >>
> >> Is there any particular reason why the JavaDoc and numerous examples
> state
> >> that the return of a @Parameters method is Collection, when it in fact
> it
> >> may only be a List<Object[]>?
> >>
> >> tx.,
> >>
> >> Raphael
> >>
> >>
> >> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >
